Package com.admob.android.ads

The AdMob SDK for Android provides the tools you need to embed ads within your Android application.

See:
          Description

Interface Summary
AdListener Implement this interface to be notified when an ad is received from the servers.
 

Class Summary
Ad Encapsulates an AdMob ad.
AdManager Provides data required to deliver ads.
AdView A view containing an ad.
SimpleAdListener Empty implementations of the AdListener methods provided as a convenience for anyone wishing to implement a subset of the methods.
 

Enum Summary
AdManager.Gender Male and Female genders.
 

Package com.admob.android.ads Description

The AdMob SDK for Android provides the tools you need to embed ads within your Android application.

The class you will most frequently use is AdView. It defines an ad widget that you can place into your layout. Application-level settings, such as specifying the user's gender, are done with methods in the AdManager class.

Setup

Including the Jar

Add the Jar file included with the SDK to your Android project as an external library. In your project's root directory create a subdirectory libs (this will already be done for you if you used Android's activitycreator tool). Copy the AdMob Jar file into that directory.

For Eclipse projects:

  • Go to the Properties of your project (right-click on your project from the Package Explorer tab and select Properties)
  • Select "Java Build Path" from left panel
  • Select "Libraries" tab from the main window
  • Click on "Add JARs..."
  • Select the JAR copied to the libs directory
  • Click "OK" to add the SDK to your android project

AndroidManifest.xml

You will need your AdMob publisher ID. It was given to you when creating your Android application on www.admob.com. It is a 15-character code like a1496ced2842262.

Just before the closing </application> tag copy-and-paste the following XML to set your publisher ID and track installs from AdMob ads. Then replace YOUR_ID_HERE with your 15-character publisher ID. 

                <!-- The application's publisher ID assigned by AdMob -->
                <meta-data android:value="YOUR_ID_HERE" android:name="ADMOB_PUBLISHER_ID" />
                
                <!-- Track Market installs -->            
                <receiver android:name="com.admob.android.ads.analytics.InstallReceiver" android:exported="true">
                        <intent-filter>
                                <action android:name="com.android.vending.INSTALL_REFERRER" />
                        </intent-filter>
                </receiver>
                
        </application>

If you are using Google Analytics do not list its receiver that consumes the INSTALL_REFERRER intent! The com.google.android.apps.analytics.AnalyticsReceiver will be called by InstallReceiver.

Make sure Internet permission is already included before closing the </manifest> tag: 

                <!-- AdMob SDK requires Internet permission -->
                <uses-permission android:name="android.permission.INTERNET" />
        </manifest>

If your application has ACCESS_COARSE_LOCATION or ACCESS_FINE_LOCATION permissions instruct the AdMob SDK whether to use it for targeting ads. Location information may increase the amount of money your application makes. However, the default is not to use it and to log a warning asking you to explicitly opt-in or opt-out. Either call AdManager.setAllowUseOfLocation before making ad requests or insert the following line in AndroidManifest.xml just before the closing </application> tag with either "true" or "false": 

                <meta-data android:value="true" android:name="ADMOB_ALLOW_LOCATION_FOR_ADS" />
        </application>

attrs.xml

The attrs.xml file specifies custom AdView attributes in XML layout files. If your application does not already have an /res/values/attrs.xml file then create one and copy-and-paste the following into it. If you do have that file then just add the declare-styleable element: 
        <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
        <resources>
                <declare-styleable name="com.admob.android.ads.AdView">
                        <attr name="backgroundColor" format="color" />
                        <attr name="primaryTextColor" format="color" />
                        <attr name="secondaryTextColor" format="color" />
                        <attr name="keywords" format="string" />
                        <attr name="refreshInterval" format="integer" />
                </declare-styleable>
        </resources>

Placing an AdView in a Layout

AdView widgets can be put into any XML layout now. The first step is to reference attrs.xml in your layout element by adding an xmlns line that includes your package name specified in AndroidManifest.xml. For instance, if your application package was com.example.admob.lunarlander, the first few lines of your AndroidManifest.xml file might look like this: 
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<manifest xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android"
    package="com.example.admob.lunarlander"
    android:versionName="20100322-ANDROID-3312276cc1406347"
    android:versionCode="20100322">
The line to add to your layout file should look like this: 
        xmlns:app="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/com.example.admob.lunarlander"
And your final layout xml should look something like this: 
<FrameLayout 
xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android"
xmlns:app="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/com.example.admob.lunarlander" >

        <!-- omitting other parts of layout -->     
    
        <!-- Place an AdMob ad at the bottom of the screen. -->
        <!-- It has white text on a black background. -->
        <!-- The description of the surrounding context is 'Android game'. -->
        <com.admob.android.ads.AdView  
          android:id="@+id/ad" 
          app:backgroundColor="#000000"
          app:primaryTextColor="#FFFFFF"
          app:secondaryTextColor="#CCCCCC"
          app:keywords="Android game"
        />

     </RelativeLayout>
         
</FrameLayout>

For example a simple screen with only an ad on it would look like: 

        <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
        <LinearLayout 
                xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android"
                xmlns:app="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/com.admob.android.example"
                android:orientation="vertical"
                android:layout_width="fill_parent"
                android:layout_height="fill_parent">
    
                <com.admob.android.ads.AdView  
                        android:id="@+id/ad" 
                        android:layout_width="fill_parent" 
                        android:layout_height="wrap_content"
                        app:backgroundColor="#000000"
                        app:primaryTextColor="#FFFFFF"
                        app:secondaryTextColor="#CCCCCC"
                        app:keywords="Android Game"
                />
                        
        </LinearLayout>

Test Mode

When integrating AdMob ads into your application it is recommended to use test mode. In test mode test ads are always returned (whereas an ad request may not fill on a regular request).

Test mode is enabled on a per-device basis. This ensures that if test mode is accidentally left on when publishing to the Market users will not see them.

To enable test mode for a device, first request an ad, then look in LogCat for a line like the following: 

        To get test ads on the emulator use AdManager.setTestDevices...
Once you have the device ID you can enable test mode by calling AdManager.setTestDevices: 
        AdManager.setTestDevices( new String[] {
                AdManager.TEST_EMULATOR,             // Android emulator
        //      "E83D20734F72FB3108F104ABC0FFC738",  // My T-Mobile G1 test phone
        } );

Once you have successfully requested test ads, try clicking on each type of test ad to make sure it works properly from your application. The type of test ad returned is changed with AdManager.setTestAction.

Example

Included with this SDK is a Lunar Lander example. This is the same example found in the Android SDK except it shows an AdMob ad when the game is paused or over.

The example's build script demonstrates how to obfuscate the source using ProGuard. To get obfuscation working make sure the proguard.jar property at the top of build.xml points to your local copy.

Tips for Ad Placement

Ads are best placed at natural break points in your application. Correctly answering "when" and "where" to show ads can significantly increase revenue. Users are most likely to click on ads at the end of some activity. For example, ads in games perform best on game over screens and worst when shown during game play.

Help

If something is going wrong the first step is to look in Android's LogCat window. Make sure the Android Eclipse plug-in is installed. Then open it from the menu Window -> Show View -> LogCat. All AdMob logging is done using the tag "AdMobSDK".

AdMob Support is also available to help work through any problems.

Related Documentation

  • AdMob Home
  • AdMob Publisher Discussion Group
  • Google's Android JavaDoc
  • Contact support@admob.com with bugs, questions, or feedback!
